reviewText: Finally managed to track down the original U.S. release by Tai Seng. All In is set in the life of Kim In Ha, Lee Byun Hun, his friends and the love of his life Min Su Yeon, Song Hye Kyo. The series starts of with a teenage In Ha befriending Su Yeon, who later would be ophaned due to the death of her father. Afterwards, In Ha planned on taking revenge be setting fire to the gangster's hideout only to accidentally kill the leader and is imprisoned for seven years. The series then starts with all of the trials In Ha goes through in order for him to be with Su Yeon.Since I have now have both the Tai Seng version and the Speedy version I'll let you guys know what the main differences are. There's really only two main differences. First is the picture quality. Tai Seng is far superior to that of Speedy. Picture, although not as good as the newer series, is a huge improvement over Speedy as Speedy crams 3 episodes per disc but the problem is the disc size. Tai Seng is dual layer and Speedy is singler layer so the picture is heavily pixelated on the Speedy version. This portion didn't really bother me with Speedy as it was the only one I could find at the time.The second one is the subtitles. Although both are great, Speedy's are a split second slow. Words would be spoken followed by a slightly delayed English subtitles. Tai Seng, so far as I'm just now rewatching it, are on time with the spoken language.If these two Speedy faults doesn't bother you then I guess the Speedy version will suffice as the Tai Seng version is extremely hard to find. However, if you can find the Tai Seng version, go with that.I will update my review if I find out later the subs are messed up for the Tai Seng version. If not, take it as they're great and doesn't have any problems. I only state this because I've had problems with their subs several times with the last one being from My Fair Lady.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Big cast, solid stable script, locations of Las Vegas (yes!) and Korea.  Loosely based on life of South Koran gambler and martial arts champ,  JImmy Cha who actually won millions in professional poker tournaments.  series takes a larger view of gambling as a theme of life's choices.  Play the hand dealt, cheat, pass, raise.  Quit the deal or play All In.  Subplots of revenge,  gangs, hotel and casino resorts, fate, true love, spirituality and loyalty.  A big buffet, lots of glitter, beautiful actresses, and gorgeous scenery.  Ending warps up too fast, as some Korean series have a habit, leaving some loose ends.  Entertaining series on a long, cold weekend.
summary: Pro Gambler best his life and love
Title: N/A

reviewText: Maybe it's just that the Chinese dvds have incredibly clearer pictures but the lead actress really looks at the apex of her beauty in this drama. The English subtitles are less insane than the Chinese dvds for Winter Sonata and 18 vs. 29.  This drama was produced after Sandglass and has a similar narrative style even the music sounds the same.  I didn't mind buying this drama sight unseen because I remember its hype and popularity and most importantly, the price is right at under $25.  I would prefer that a dvd packaged be done well and mass produced at an affordable price than this unhealthy for the consumer pricing nearer to the $100 mark. It makes people feel bad that a mere entertainment item is out of reach.  It's not a car nor a house, it's not even a winter coat.  Lower the average prices PLEASE.
summary: Miss Song's beauty at its crispiest.

reviewText: I was disappointed with this drama. I have read the original book which was based on a real life story of a Korean poker player-baduk player Cha Min-soo. The drama turns it into something totally different. I don't understand why they even bothered to title it "All-in" ? They would even advertise as "Based on real story...". I don't think so, 'very very loosely based on' at best.
summary: Not as good as the original book
